Chapter:
Basic cvs-commands for &GAP; developers
The source code for the &GAP; kernel, the &GAP; library and most &GAP; packages is kept in a central repository in St. Andrews. The tool to administrate this repository is called CVS, the Concurrent Versions System.
This chapter recalls some basic CVS commands. Most of the time very few commands are sufficient. But there are also rare tasks like tagging a new release branch, or transferring changes from one branch to another, for which some developers may not remember the details by heart.
Basic commands to use one CVS branch
If you know basic CVS usage, you can skip this section apart from the address of the &GAP; CVS repository below.
To work on the &GAP; source code, one checks out a working copy. All changes are first done in this working copy and then commited to the repository. CVS automatically takes care of revision numbers for all the files and keeps all old revisions in the repository.
To check out a working copy, you first have to have the password for access to the development version. Once you have this, you have to do the following exactly once:
cvs -d :pserver:gap@cvs.gap-system.org:/gap/CVS login
After that you have to type in the password. Your local CVS client will put something into ~/.cvspass in your home directory.
Now you can check out the complete source code by doing:
cvs -d :pserver:gap@cvs.gap-system.org:/gap/CVS checkout 4.0
This will create a directory called 4.0 in the current directory, under which your working copy resides. Note that this needs about 500 Mb of disk space.
Every subdirectory under the tree 4.0 contains a subdirectory called CVS. Usually you should not touch these. They are used for CVS interals.
From now on you can always update your working copy from the repository by doing
cvs update
in any subdirectory of 4.0 (including 4.0). This will update the current directory and all its subdirectories recursively.
CVS will report on the status of the update:
U or P means the local file was updated/patched by CVS.
M means the local file has changes that are not in CVS (use cvs diff to see which)
C means conflicts, see below.
Note that if you made changes to any files and the repository has changed since your last update or checkout, then CVS tries to merge the changes into your working copy. Usually this works well, however conflicts may occur (indicated by a letter C before the filename in the output of cvs update, see above). In this case you have to edit the files by hand, looking for occurances of the string <<<<<< to resolve the conflicts.
Note also, that newly created subdirectories in the repository are not automatically checked out by cvs update. To achieve this, use
cvs update -d
When you have changed files in your working copy, you can use
cvs commit
in the corresponding directory to commit your changes to the repository. This command commits all changes in all files in the current directory and in all subdirectories recursively. If you want to commit only changes to certain files, then put their names after the cvs commit command.
You are asked to submit a log entry describing your changes. This log entry is stored together with the changed files in the repository. To this end, an editor is opened and after saving and closing it the commit is performed. It is good practice to put your name or initials into the log entry, such that one knows afterwards, whom to ask about a particular change.
If you created new files you have to do
cvs add FILENAME
in the directory of the new file, with FILENAME replaced with the name of the new file. This marks the file for addition in the next commit, that is, it will appear in the repository after the next commit.
Note that non-ASCII files have to be added with the option -kb (directly after the add). This prevents certain changes that CVS automatically do to text files, which could destroy binary files. Usually it is not good idea at all to put binary files into the repository, because things like differences between revisions, compact storage of different revisions, and merging of conflicting changes do not work well. Also lots of disk space is needed to keep old revisions of binary files.
To remove a file from the repository, first delete it in your working copy and then use
cvs remove FILENAME
analogously. Note that old revisions of the file still reside in the repository, however, checkouts no longer fetch them.
Revision numbers of files
CVS automatically keeps a revision number for each revision of each file. For every commit, this revision number is increased. You can access any old revision of a file by using commands like
cvs update -r 1.17 FILENAME
which retrieves revision 1.17 of file FILENAME. Note that from this command on further cvs update calls will always retain this revision of that file in your working copy, the revision is sticky. If you want to get rid of this sticky revision and update again to the latest revision, just use
cvs update -A FILENAME
You can get information about the revision in your working copy and in the repository by doing
cvs status FILENAME
This also shows you possible sticky tags. Another interesting command is
cvs log FILENAME
which shows you the revision history together with the log entries of the file FILENAME. In addition, at the beginning of the output a list of symbolic tags and their meaning in terms of revision numbers is shown. A symbolic tag marks all the revisions of all files having some common property. For example, the symbolic tag GAP4R4 refers to the revision that was last released with &GAP; version 4, release 4. See the next section for details.
You can always use symbolic tags instead of revision numbers, for example in a call like
cvs update -r GAP4R4
Branches and the revisions tree
The set of revision numbers of a file in the CVS repository is not necessarily totally ordered. Rather, one can fork of branches such that a partial order like a tree results.
For &GAP;, the development version is the main branch, and a new branch is created for every major release. So for example the branch for the currently released version of &GAP; version 4, release 4 has the symbolic tag GAP4R4. By convention, changes that shall go into the released version with the next bugfix or update are kept in that branch.
Therefore, any change in the development version, that shall be published with the next bugfix or update, has to be transferred into the released branch. This is done as follows:
We assume that you have a checked out working copy of the development version and that the change is done in file xyz.g between revisions 1.98 and 1.99, already checked into the repository. If more than one file was changed, you have to repeat the process described below for each of those. Note that the revision numbers are different for each file!
The first step is to check out the latest version in the released branch. Assuming that we work on the GAP4R4 branch, this is done by:
cvs update -r GAP4R4 xyz.g
Now we have to change this revision in the same way as the file was changed between revisions 1.98 and 1.99 in the development version. This is done as follows:
cvs update -j 1.98 -j 1.99 xyz.g
Note that this might produce conflicts (see section ), which have to be resolved by hand (search for the string <<<<<<).
Now the change has to be commited to the GAP4R4 branch by
cvs commit xyz.g
and entering a log entry describing the change. Note, that the file in your working copy is now sticky to the GAP4R4 branch and you have to do
cvs update -A xyz.g
to get rid of the sticky tag and again work with the latest development version.
Remember to edit 4.0/dev/Update (see section ), such that the information about your change is not lost.
Another possibility is to check out a full working copy of the released branch. This is done by using the -r GAP4R4 option already in the cvs checkout command described in section . If you do this you can skip the two steps cvs update -r GAP4R4 xyz.g and cvs update -A xyz.g above. On the other hand, you need twice as much disk space to keep two full working copies.
To be continued with Forking off a new Branch for a release.
Digging out differences between revisions, log entries, and change dates
Internally CVS uses the programs diff and patch to keep track of different revisions of files. In the repository, all old revisions are kept by only storing differences between revisions. The user also has access to those differences with the commands described in this section.
To show the differences between say revisions 1.27 and 1.28 of file xyz.g you can use the following command:
cvs diff -r 1.27 -r 1.28 -u xyz.g
Note that the -u switch chooses the so-called unified output format (see man diff for different possibilities). Of course, the output format is a matter of taste.
Often it is convenient to first check the log entries (see section ) using cvs log xyz.g to find out between which revisions the change you are interested in has been applied.
One can also specify symbolic tags or dates for either of the revisions. In this case, dates refer to the most recent version no later than the date you specify:
cvs diff -u -D 1997/11/24 -r GAP4R4 xyz.g
If you give only one revision number, tag, or date, your current working copy (may it be changed locally or not) is compared to that revision. If you use cvs diff -u xyz.g without any revision, your current working copy is compared to the latest revision in the repository.
